channel.title: Advice on creating a Java engine for 2d game development?
channel.description:
I'm currently working on an engine (which is kinda crappy right now) that I'm planning to redo. It's mainly graphical based for users to create basic 2D games currently only following basic features such as adding objects, basic player movement with arrow keys and that's about it.
What would you guys go around doing something some what similar because right now I'm using Swing, and relying on KeyListener for all my action events which imo is not really the best approach because its not even half working lol.
Any thoughts/ideas?

item.title: Advice on creating a Java engine for 2d game development?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Sorry if I was unclear to - I was not quiet planning on making my own library but more of a multi platform base for people to use and using slick looks cool

[quote=“Lin, post:8, topic:508244”]Here’s how I would make a 2D game engine:

-Create a base class or interface for game objects and inside it have properties like whether or not it’s enabled, etc…
-Create a base class or interface for drawable objects and inside it have properties like its position, whether or not it’s visible, etc…
-Have a method that pre-processes objects, processes objects, and (optional) post-processes objects. Unless specified, only process the objects in view.
-Render all of the objects in view, automatically translating them based on the viewport. Since you have a base class for drawable objects, you could easily make other objects render in a specific way

And that’s pretty much it![/quote]

YuSoSmart? Gave me a cool idea

item.title: Advice on creating a Java engine for 2d game development?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Here’s how I would make a 2D game engine:

-Create a base class or interface for game objects and inside it have properties like whether or not it’s enabled, etc…
-Create a base class or interface for drawable objects and inside it have properties like its position, whether or not it’s visible, etc…
-Have a method that pre-processes objects, processes objects, and (optional) post-processes objects. Unless specified, only process the objects in view.
-Render all of the objects in view, automatically translating them based on the viewport. Since you have a base class for drawable objects, you could easily make other objects render in a specific way

And that’s pretty much it!
